unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Scene
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Scene

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and indie film fanatics! Ever feel like you're stuck in a cinematic rut, watching the same old stuff on Netflix? Well, let me tell you, the answer is out there, shining bright like a Raj Kapoor smile: Film Festivals!
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs or indie film fanatics! Ever feel like you're stuck in a cinematic rut, watching the same old stuff on Netflix? Well, let me tell you, the answer is out there, shining bright like a Raj Kapoor smile: Film Festivals!

unnormalised: These aren't just stuffy events for critics (though they're there too!). Film festivals are a total blast. Think awesome movies you won't find anywhere else, Q&As with directors who might reveal behind-the-scenes secrets of movies. Plus, the vibe! It's a buzzing atmosphere of film lovers geeking out together.
normalised: These aren't just stuffy events for critics (though they're there too!). Film festivals are a total blast. It's a buzzing atmosphere of film lovers geeking out together.

unnormalised: In India, we have some amazing film festivals. The International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa is massive, a real grandaddy of them all. Then there's the Jio MAMI Mumbai Film Festival, which brings cutting-edge Indian and international cinema right to the heart of Bollywood. Imagine bumping into Anurag Kashyap while grabbing a vada pav!

Then there's the Jio M A M I Mumbai Film Festival, which brings cutting-edge Indian and international cinema right to the heart of Bollywood. Imagine bumping into Anurag Kashyap while grabbing a vada pav!

unnormalised: But it's not just the biggies. Look out for smaller regional festivals too. They often showcase incredible local talent and unique stories you won't see anywhere else. I recently went to a short film festival in Pune – a 100 Rs entry fee got me access to some truly mind-blowing documentaries!

unnormalised: Going to a film festival is like going on a mini-adventure. You'll discover new filmmakers, new genres, and maybe even a new perspective on life. You might watch a film about rural Rajasthan, a thriller from Kerala, or a quirky comedy from Europe – all in one day.

unnormalised: So, ditch the predictable rom-com and dive into the world of film festivals. Check out the websites, book your tickets (early bird catches the worm!), and get ready for a cinematic experience you won't forget. Maybe you'll even be inspired to make your own film someday! Who knows, you might be the next Satyajit Ray – just with slightly less 60's fashion.
